subject: Re: [junit] Constructor called multiple times?

messageBody:
On 03 Apr 2007 16:05:52 -0700, David Saff <saff@...> wrote:

> 2b) If your tests are not cheap to initialize and run because they're
> actually integration tests, acceptance tests, or end-to-end system tests,
> then you might want state to persist, trading off safety for performance.

I don't understand how maintaining read-only state trades off safety?

If the state is read-only, the test methods are still completely
independent from each other, where do I lose safety by maintaining
this state in-between invocations?

> In JUnit 3.8, you can use TestSetup for this state, and in JUnit 4, you can
> use @BeforeClass with statics

Statics are extremely problematic with integration tools (ant, maven
or IDE's) and they are also inherently a lot less thread-safe,
therefore preventing you from leveraging parallelism.

> or you can search Google for "JUnit
> OneInstance.class", which will give you a solution allowing you to only
> instantiate your test class once.

Similary, I have always found JUnit tests hard to run reliably when
they start depending on specialized runners. Do the Eclipse and IDEA
plug-ins support @RunWith?

Anyway, I think the confusion of the original author is still
justified: since both the constructor and setUp() are invoked before
every test method, why have both?

--
Cédric
